text: The third morning arrives too quickly. The snow has paused, leaving a thin crust of ice that crunches underfoot.
When I push open the inn door, the air carries a faint metallic scent—like someone has been sharpening blades nearby.
From the direction of the North Gate comes the sound of synchronized marching—steady, deliberate, forcing chaos into rhythm.
I follow the street to the open ground outside the gate. The fog hasn’t lifted. The barrier’s blue glow clings to the wall like a thin membrane, pulsing faintly.
Dozens of soldiers have gathered. Shields grounded. Spears upright. No laughter—only breath and the soft scrape of armor.
They don’t look like men waiting for orders. They look like men waiting for someone who can make them believe they’ll survive the night.
Alicia stands at the front. No red dress. No soft cloak. She wears light armor, sleeves tightened, as if preparing for something routine.
Her hair is simply tied back. Her face still pale—but her eyes clearer than the past two days. A clarity born from pressing exhaustion down to the bone.
“Listen carefully.”
“No heroics. No wasted courage. Just follow instructions.”
She gestures to the center of the field. Her voice isn’t loud—but it steadies everyone instinctively.
“First row, shields up. One arm’s distance apart. Second row, spears half-step forward—thrust only, do not chase. Third row, archers switch to short volleys. Conserve arrows.”
The commands come like memorized lines. No hesitation—only sequence.
The soldiers move instantly. Shields slam down. Spears align. Archers reposition. The formation tightens under her voice.
I stand at the edge, palms cold. Her precision doesn’t feel trained—it feels repeated.
She steps into the line and adjusts a young soldier’s shield angle herself.
“Don’t let it shake. If you shake, someone behind you dies.”
The recruit pales—but steadies.
“Good. Remember that feeling. Tonight, hold it.”
She glances at the barrier’s glow—checking an invisible measure. Then draws her sword.
The blade flashes once. No flourish—just a demonstration of thrust, recover, step.
“Don’t copy my swing. Copy my recovery.”
“You live first. You strike again later.”
When she says “again,” her tone is calm—as if speaking about another meal. My chest tightens.
The formation practices. Shield wall advances. Spear line pushes. Footsteps grow synchronized. The cold wind still bites—but for the first time, it feels survivable.
Then—small running footsteps from the side street.
A few children slip out, clutching cloth bundles and paper bags like they’ve snuck away.
A girl with braided hair approaches timidly, lifting a small wrapped bundle on tiptoe.
I almost step forward to stop her—but she’s already there.
Alicia looks down.
Inside the cloth: broken pieces of baked biscuits and a few candies wrapped in crinkled paper.
“Miss… this is for you.”
“You looked really cool just now!”
The soldiers tense instinctively, afraid this softness might break the rhythm.
Alicia is silent for two seconds—like she’s forcing something back down her throat.
“Thank you.”
She accepts the bundle. Doesn’t eat. Instead, she ties it securely at her waist—positioned so it won’t interfere with drawing her blade.
“Go home. Don’t linger.”
“Okay!”
The child runs off, waving once—like she believes this story ends in victory.
Alicia’s gaze follows briefly. Then she locks it away again.
“Resume training.”
“Shield wall, ten steps. Halt. Archers, two short volleys. Halt. Spear line fill the gap. Repeat.”
The soldiers respond in unison. Movements steadier now.
I watch her move between them—like someone dismantling disaster into manageable steps.
And I know: the more orderly this is, the more certain she is about what will happen.
I almost ask her—how many mornings like this have you already lived?
But I don’t. Because she’s busy convincing everyone else they’ll survive tonight.
And from the beginning—she never counted herself among them.
